text: I believe the "write for one person" approach is all about knowing your audience and writing in a language that the audience, whether it's Jane in accounting or Bob in logistics, understands and relates to. And obviously it's about following the basic principles of writing such as active voice, simple wording, logical structure, and tackling your audience pain points.

elements.text: I believe the "write for one person" approach is all about knowing your audience and writing in a language that the audience, whether it's Jane in accounting or Bob in logistics, understands and relates to. text:
:wave: Hello people, has anyone built a non-branded site with information about a category at large?

An insurance brand is thinking about creating a standalone site with info about the category--accident insurance--generally, to help build category awareness and understanding.

Good idea or stick to content on the brand's site and blog? On a non-branded site, what's the right balance in linking to the brand/talking about the brand?

Wondering your thoughts on this nascent idea.

elements.text:
Hello people, has anyone built a non-branded site with information about a category at large?

An insurance brand is thinking about creating a standalone site with info about the category--accident insurance--generally, to help build category awareness and understanding.

Good idea or stick to content on the brand's site and blog? On a non-branded site, what's the right balance in linking to the brand/talking about the brand?

Wondering your thoughts on this nascent idea.

text: Thanks all! Great food for thought here.

elements.text: Thanks all! Great food for thought here.

text: i think it should be like a sub section on the existing site. however, i can see it being effective as its own site. Might try it out on the brand's site first as sort of an MVP. Insurnace companies could really benefit from using some different kinds of content too (i think)

elements.text: i think it should be like a sub section on the existing site. however, i can see it being effective as its own site. Might try it out on the brand's site first as sort of an MVP. Insurnace companies could really benefit from using some different kinds of content too (i think)

text: How to plan and execute SEO content. From keyword research and identifying searcher's intent, to writing with clarity/optimizing for snippets, optimizing headlines, images, alt tags, captions, adding strategic outbound and internal links, and well-written meta descriptions.

elements.text: How to plan and execute SEO content. From keyword research and identifying searcher's intent, to writing with clarity/optimizing for snippets, optimizing headlines, images, alt tags, captions, adding strategic outbound and internal links, and well-written meta descriptions.

text: Many content writers already know bits and pieces of the above, but sending them through the entire process from end-to-end really helps tie everything together.

elements.text: Many content writers already know bits and pieces of the above, but sending them through the entire process from end-to-end really helps tie everything together.

text: I think you really need dedication from the top to make it an independent site that’s not just designed to sell what your company is offering. Ideally, perhaps, partnering with a complementary brand(s) to bring it to life and make it more vendor-neutral. I created one of these category sites and 1) it was basically treated as a side project, not a real campaign with its own budget, resources, etc. 2) it started to get left behind due to other priorities pretty quickly, meaning it became out of date. Something like this needs a long-term plan again signed off on at the highest levels with a commitment to properly fund and keep it updated.

elements.text: I think you really need dedication from the top to make it an independent site that’s not just designed to sell what your company is offering. Ideally, perhaps, partnering with a complementary brand(s) to bring it to life and make it more vendor-neutral. I created one of these category sites and 1) it was basically treated as a side project, not a real campaign with its own budget, resources, etc. 2) it started to get left behind due to other priorities pretty quickly, meaning it became out of date. Something like this needs a long-term plan again signed off on at the highest levels with a commitment to properly fund and keep it updated.

text: Hi guys, I see people promoting or asking to join LinkedIn "engagement pods", where they all like and comment on each other's content. Does that actually work? Is there any value in participating?

elements.text: Hi guys, I see people promoting or asking to join LinkedIn "engagement pods", where they all like and comment on each other's content. Does that actually work? Is there any value in participating?

text: Only lead to vanity metrics if what you're posting isn't compelling. I also assume LinkedIn's algorithm will soon be smart enough to see the same people are just liking your stuff over and over again.

elements.text: Only lead to vanity metrics if what you're posting isn't compelling. I also assume LinkedIn's algorithm will soon be smart enough to see the same people are just liking your stuff over and over again.

text: It works as long as you mix it in with normal engagement and assuming you have a decent “pod”. Plenty of folks that just drop a standard message which makes no sense. Also, lots of pods have people with varying backgrounds — from psychologists to cleaners and everything in between. It just doesn’t make sense if all of them engage with your post about say content marketing

elements.text: It works as long as you mix it in with normal engagement and assuming you have a decent “pod”. Plenty of folks that just drop a standard message which makes no sense. Also, lots of pods have people with varying backgrounds — from psychologists to cleaners and everything in between. It just doesn’t make sense if all of them engage with your post about say content marketing

text:
I think it makes sense to stick it on the brand’s site to piggyback off of the authority of the brand’s site, unless the brand wants to build the authority of this new standalone site all by itself.

I tried building a standalone site once related to my company and it was too much of an uphill battle to gain backlinks, authority, etc. Shifting to building pages off our main company page now.

elements.text:

text: There are tools that you have to grant access to your LinkedIn that’ll do the engagement for you but I’d never do that.

elements.text: There are tools that you have to grant access to your LinkedIn that’ll do the engagement for you but I’d never do that.

text: This is what made blog rings so popular back in the day. Whenever someone’s blog post would go out, everyone in the community would comment on that person’s post to help that person rank. I don’t think LinkedIn will get as sophisticated at sniffing out this behavior, but at the end of the day people can see your comment activity and may interpret it as spam.

elements.text: This is what made blog rings so popular back in the day. Whenever someone’s blog post would go out, everyone in the community would comment on that person’s post to help that person rank. I don’t think LinkedIn will get as sophisticated at sniffing out this behavior, but at the end of the day people can see your comment activity and may interpret it as spam.

text:
They can definitely work if you pick the right podmates - see here about the "new" algorithm and dwell time in relation to upstream/downstream engagement and views: <https://engineering.linkedin.com/blog/2020/understanding-feed-dwell-time>

I think the challenge with pods is that if it comes off inauthentic or the content is lacking, it's not going to drive long term growth and engagement. You have to be very selective about who you choose to work with and make sure they're naturally active on linkedin as well otherwise its wasted time

attachments.title: Understanding dwell time to improve LinkedIn feed ranking
attachments.text: Co-authors: Siddharth Dangi, Johnson Jia, Manas Somaiya, and Ying Xuan
attachments.fallback: Understanding dwell time to improve LinkedIn feed ranking

elements.text: They can definitely work if you pick the right podmates - see here about the "new" algorithm and dwell time in relation to upstream/downstream engagement and views:

I think the challenge with pods is that if it comes off inauthentic or the content is lacking, it's not going to drive long term growth and engagement. You have to be very selective about who you choose to work with and make sure they're naturally active on linkedin as well otherwise its wasted time

text: I've done this on Instagram, and agree with what Sam says above. A lot of the time it was very obvious who was in the "pod" - I think it can work a lot better if it's people you're actually friends with or who you would naturally comment on because then it would be a lot more relevant.

elements.text: I've done this on Instagram, and agree with what Sam says above. text: Hey there! I run <http://workbrighter.co/newsletter/>

attachments.title: Work Brighter Weekly
attachments.text: Ready to Work Brighter instead of just smarter?JOIN 2,500+ PRODUCTIVE UNICORNS PERSONALIZING PRODUCTIVITY AND CREATING THEIR OWN RULES FOR WORKProductivity isn't black and white.Nope, that shit is super personal, and it takes more than one tool, app, framework, 'lifehack,' or system to unlock it. So why is so much of the advice about 'working smarter' so one-size-fits-all? Work Brighter is the productivity newsletter that helps you go beyond 'working smarter'......to a version of productivity that makes room for 'unproductive' things like rest, self-care, and fun. What we call working brighter. Every Monday morning, you'll receive stories, links, and resources to help
